title: The Secretum was accepted as both historical and Aristotelian in the Middle Ages and circulated very widely. For Gower’s use of it
‘Noght in the Registre of Venus’: Gower’s English Mirror for Princes

Gilbert,“Notes on the Influence of the Secretum Secretorum

Although it was ultimately based on an eighth-century Arabic source, the Secretum was twice translated into Latin (in the mid-twelfth and early thirteenth centuries) and survives in over 500 manuscripts in that language alone.At least thirteen Middle English versions from the fifteenth century are known, including a rhymed translation begun by John Lydgate (and finished by Benedict Burgh).
